posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

The fact that iconodulia is foreign to the earliest Church Fathers was one of the key reasons that made me leave the catechumenate. When one learns that aniconism was common to the early Fathers, or at minimum that there is no evidence that early Christian art was bowed before, kissed, or anything else, it is hard to believe the practice is apostolic. The arguments of John of Damascus and Nicaea II have more in common with Porphyry’s theories of semiotics that he uses to defend pagan idolatry from Christian polemics.

The other main reason was Marian hyperdulia. Just read the Akathist to the Theotokos, where she is called ‘salvation of my soul’ and ‘propitiation of my sins’, and is called the cloud in the wilderness in Exodus, and the true manna, thus equating her totally with Jesus Christ. In some of the prayers used in Orthodoxy Mary is also called the ‘true vine’, which is a title of Jesus in John 15. We sing ‘true Theotokos we magnify you’, but Mary said, ‘my soul magnifies the Lord’ in the Gospel. I love Mary, and the miracles God worked in her, but this is just too far for me. I started to see idolatry everywhere and began to take the Reformers seriously

>>14320600
>Care to bring some proofs?
Epistle of Barnabas (c. 70-130 AD)
Mentions that the bronze serpent is an apparent contradiction of God’s command against images, but it was used to symbolize Jesus in advance (Chapter 12)

Justin Martyr (100-165 AD)
Mocks pagans in his First Apology for attempting to depict God, who has “ineffable glory and form” with “things that are corruptible” (chapter 9)
Chapter 95 of the Dialogue with Trypho mentions that the bronze serpent was an apparent contradiction of the commandment against images, says it was a sign [of Christ]
Quotes Sophocles, a Greek dramatist in his ‘Hortatory Address to the Greeks’ on the foolishness of ‘Images of the gods in stone and wood’
Quotes the Sibyl [Pagan prophetess] to demonstrate that “images and figures of dead men” is straying “from the Immortal’s ways”

Aristides (2nd century)
“But the Christians, O King, while they went about and made search, have found the truth; and as we learned from their writings, they have come nearer to truth and genuine knowledge than the rest of the nations… they do not worship idols made in the image of man” (Apology of Aristides 15)

Irenaeus of Lyons (c. 130-202 AD)
In ‘Against Heresies’ book 1, chapter 25, Irenaeus mentions that the Gnostic followers of Carpocrates “possess images”, and “They also have other modes of honouring these images, after the same manner of the Gentiles”

Tertullian (c. 155 - c. 220 AD)
Mentions in Book II, chapter XXII of his Five Books Against Marcion that the similitude of all heavenly, earthly or aquatic things are forbidden by God. The bronze serpent was not a violation, nor were the cherubim of the ark—the serpent was merely a ”cure” for those afflicted by the fiery serpente, and the angels on the ark were “adapted to ornamentation”, and because “they are not found in that form of similitude, in reference to which the prohibition is given” .
“Every form or formling, therefore, claims to be called an idol” (On Idolatry, chapter 3).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14320600
>Care to bring some proofs?
Clement of Alexandria (c. 150 - c. 215)
Mentions that Moses enacted expressly that no graven, molten, moulded nor painted likenesses should be made, “that we may not cleave to the things of sense, but pass to intellectual objects: for familiarity with the sight disparages the reverence of what is divine; and to worship that which is immaterial by matter, is to dishonour it by sense” (Stromata, book V, chapter 5)

Hippolytus of Rome (c. 170 - 235 AD)
Like Irenaeus, Hippolytus writes of Carpocratian gnostics and how they ‘’make counterfeit images of Christ, alleging these were in existence during the time which our Lord was on earth, and that theh were fashioned by Pilate” (Refutation of All Heresies, chapter 20)

Minucius Felix (died c. 250 AD)
“Why have they [Christians] no altars, no temples, no acknowledged images? Why do they never speak openly, never congregate freely, unless for the reason that what they adore and conceal is either worthy of punishment, or something to be ashamed of?” (Octavius, chapter 10)
“But do you think that we conceal what we worship, if we have not temples and altars? And yet what image of God shall I make, since, if you think rightly, man himself is the image of God?” (Octavius, chapter 32)

Origen of Alexandria (c. 185 - c. 253 AD)
In Contra Celsum Origen repeatedly mentions that Christians have a “contempt for idols, and images of all kinds”
Chapter 8 of Book V has Celsus say that Jews bow to angels and heaven, but Origen says this is not Jewish at all, but a transgression of God’s law and the prophets. Same for Christians.
In Book VI, Origen says that we are not to worship the Father with images, but “in truth”, which “came by Jesus Christ”
In Book VII, mentions that those “taught in the school of Jesus Christ, have rejected all images and statues”

Epiphanius, bishop of Salamis (c. 310-320 - 403 AD)
Comes across an image of Christ and a saint in a church and “tore it asunder”, for it was “contrary to the teaching of the Scriptures”.

Synod of Elvira (305-6 AD)
Images should not be in churches “so that what is venerated and worshiped should not be painted on the walls”

Lactantius (c. 250 - c. 325)
Says in Divine Institutes, Book II, that “But in the case of God, whose spirit and influence are diffused everywhere, and can never be absent, it is plain that an image is always superfluous”

Arnobius (died c. 330 AD)
“For you are in the habit of fastening upon us a very serious charge of impiety because we do not… set up statues and images of any god…”
“We worship the gods, you say, by means of images. What then? Without these, do the gods not know that they are worshipped, and will they not think that any honor is shown to them by you?” (Against the Heathen, book VI, chapter 9)
“And whence, finally, do you know whether all these images which you form and put in the place of the immortal gods reproduce and bear a resemblance to the gods?” (Against the Heathen, book VI, chapter 10) - not strictly about Christian worship, but it is relevant to include, I think.

Augustine of Hippo (354 - 430 AD)
In reference to Christ sitting at the right hand of the Father, Augustine writes “it is unlawful for a Christian to set up any such image for God in a temple” (Of Faith and the Creed, Chapter 7)
Augustine writes in the 34th chapter of ‘Of the Morals of the Catholic Church’ of those who are ‘professors of the Christian name’ who ‘even in the true religion are superstitious’, and are ‘given up to evil passions’, among whom are ‘many worshippers of tombs and pictures’.

At 13 I had my confirmation, decided to try and get into religion. Read the bible a lot, prayed a lot, bible seemed stupid praying felt pointless, didn't feel anything, didn't notice anything, stopped bothering. As I got older I began to think more deeply than just reading the bible into logical considerations about religion and the implications of theology and realized that Christianity had some holes I couldn't reconcile and while other religions better patched said holes I didn't find them to really offer much proof beyond >>14323860 "we don't know therefore God" which is nowhere near enough proof for me to dedicate my life to something. If religion just amounted to picking a roulette number I would probably pick deism or zoroastrianism or something, but I wouldn't spend my life following those religions based on the dubious proof.

When it comes to religion I think dualistic religions are the most reasonable by making god distant and solving the problem of evil by making the satan equivalent as powerful as god, as far as theological implications go I prefer something more akin to Hinduism, I would much rather reincarnate than go to heaven, eternity is something impossible for ephemeral beings to truly grasp and thus the idea of an eternal afterlife seems inevitably boring whether a positive or negative afterlife. Something with reincarnation like Hinduism solves the issue by letting you essentially go around for another shot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14324062
You are really underestimating how absolutely devastating having the combined American and British logistic systems working against a country is. Those two countries have a terrifying capability to produce and move goods to the right place in an expedient manner when working together. They also controlled (and still control) the global financial sector and can easily pressure neutral countries into not dealing with you. The Americans joined with a fresh batch of troops who weren't exhausted from years of wartime, and an incredibly capable logistics system. It's not like pulling just the 4 million men into France to sure up the line, it's providing the 4 million men and an increase of logistics capabilities. More food, more ammo, faster resupply, more clothes, more wood and paper, more industrial equipment to make repairs, across the board. German supply lines having to shift all the eastern resources west was already a strain, but increasing industrial capacity to meet the renewed equipment in the western front is an absolute nightmare.
In World War 2, the Americans only got better at logistics and had more time to focus on building even more sophisticated supply lines. The Americans becoming the supreme leaders of the Allies was because they were the ones moving supplies to where they were needed, not because they had the strongest soldiers or largest army. Without American supplies the Soviets would have struggled much harder in the East and liberating France would have been out of the question (at least how it happened for us). The American logistics in the 2nd World War was so outrageously good it even surprised their own generals, who planned on keeping Japan occupied while focusing entirely on Europe, but found themselves being able to fight aggressively on both fronts simultaneously. In reality, bringing the Americans onto the enemy side is a deathblow even if the Germans knock out Russia (which they did in the first World War).

>>14324133
>You are really underestimating how absolutely devastating having the combined American and British logistic systems working against a country is
I don't think I am, because I don't think it matters as much in this case as it did in WW2, because the US was building up for years by the time Overlord happened. The US didn't declare war until April 1917 in WW1, which gave them only an 8-10 month timeframe to prepare for a German offensive in the West. Even still, the US had 2 million in France by the summer, and 1 million saw combat, but again this was in the Summer, after the Kaiserschlacht. I will say though my timeline was a little fucked because I thought the US declared war in late 1917 before I looked it up to make sure. In this case, the 'betrayal' idea would have to be far more compelling than just a slight break in supply for the Germans, it would've had to completely break their shit and make it extremely slow for them to restart production.

I am really wondering how much the General Strike effected the German war effort though, if it was just a break in supply that wasn't a huge deal in the end, or if it was a cataclysm that led to the end of the war, or somewhere in the middle. I lean towards the middle on this honestly, because on one hand it was just a short strike, and US troops were coming 10k/day. On the other hand, German industry was extremely stretched thin at the time, so a slight break may have been catastrophic, and there had to be some truth to the idea of "betrayal", since so many people believed in this and Hitler was easily able to capitalize with this idea.

The Assembly of Massachusetts Bay was the first which ever took exception to the right of Parliament to impose Duties or Taxes on the Colonies, whilst they had no representatives in the House of Commons. This they did in a letter to their Agent in the summer of 1764 ... From Lord North's article by Peter Thomas in 'The Biographical dictionary of British Prime Ministers', page 71
>At this moment Lord North took a policy initiative for which he has seldom been given full credit. It was a solo attempt to avert the civil war evidently threatening between Britain and its colonies. Despite the opposition of many of his colleagues and supporters he offered conciliation, albeit with the simultaneous dispatch of more army and navy units to America and after legislation to prevent colonial trade and fishing until British control had been restored. His conciliatory propositions of February 1775 offered to renounce taxation of any individual colony which agreed to pay its costs of civil government and defence. This proposal, conceding no rights to the colonists and regarded in America as deliberately divisive, would probably have been unsuccessful even if fighting had not commenced in April 1775 before news of it arrived. Formal rejection by Congress in July 1775 did not deter North from offering it again in the Peace Commission sent to America in 1776, and North’s intention was to enforce that arrangement on the colonies if Britain had won the war. North had shrewdly perceived that a return to the status quo was unrealistic, and his proposal was as far as British opinion would allow him to go. All suggestions, both contemporary and retrospective, that a more conciliatory American policy should have been essayed in 1775 ignore political reality.

I was mistaken about it being offered a third time in 1777.

They had de-Russification programs, like a big part of Soviet policy was ethnogenesis campaigns where they were going around replacing colonial and clan governments with national "Soviet republic" governments comprised of native bureaucrats and organized efforts to standardize native languages (which in some cases didn't have written forms). There was a heavy "Ukrainization" campaign in the 1920s to spread Ukrainian language books and newspapers, but Stalin's purges began targeting "bourgeois nationalists" in the Ukrainian branch of the party and that's when "Ukranization" stopped. On the other hand, the Ukrainian SSR remained bilingual until the end of the USSR. There was still a lot of "passive" Russification in Ukraine and also Belarus, but generally ethnic minorities were treated far better than before although I doubt it was perfect.

>>14319475
>So is brachycephaly just a modern degeneracy and no one ancient ancestral population was broad-headed? I sometimes hear this opinion.
Before I get to it I want you to realise something that will help you later in the post. Genetic code is not computer code. A sequence of genes can be used to synthesise proteins in several different tissues leading to morphological differences in many organs. Computer code only does a particular thing when it's "called in" to so a particular thing.

Ok so imagine a group of people. If you measure their skulls, they will have certain range of cephalic index, probably spread along the bell curve. Living in certain stable environment, they maintain this spread because natural selection doesn't benefit either side of the curve. Now if you change the environment to benefit traits that coincide with let's say brachycephaly, brachycephalic people will have more children and the average will start shifting towards their side of the graph. The genes will also start accumulating, as in if 1/3rd of the population had some sequence A contributing to this shape of school and 2/3rd had B with only 1/6th having an overlap, this disproportionately high population growth will make this overlap more common, so it's absolutely possible for such shift to be relatively rapid and ironically enough - reversible.

The reason why brachycephalic skull shape is seen as "unnatural" is based on good observation but bad priors - domesticated animals tend to have more brachycephalic skulls than their wild ancestors, so clearly a brachy man is a domesticated man*. The bad prior here is that people assume that because this shift occured in some societies, this is not natural, but that's because they fundamentally don't believe humans naturally form societies and adapt them to different conditions and that's very silly.

*Mind you domesticated is not timid. Pitbulls are brachycephalic dogs, your typical football hooligan is also likely quite brachy

Southern Schleswig was never offered to the Danes. Some within Denmark, notably PM Knud Kristensen were for it, but it was never officially requested, and never offered. posts.name: Anonymous

>>14322586
Sorry for the delay.

Well, there are plenty of spots to visit for various motives. Here are some recommendations of the top of my head.
If you want beaches there are plenty throughout the coast (some example in yellow; such as Ericeira, Nazaré(the place of the world's biggest waves), Cascais, etc.)
In terms of a religious sense /or religiously related, you also have plenty of choices (some examples in blue like Fátima(which gets pretty crowed in the 13th day of each month from May until October), Braga, or Tomar(historic home of the Templars and Order of Christ)).
Some must-see places(and which are usually recommended) are Lisbon, Porto, Sintra, which are filled with monuments and other places.
Some other places worth to see (in my opinion) would be Óbidos (a beautiful castle town; best to go during the chocolate festival; also good liqueur) and Coimbra, the academic city with a beautiful garden (avoid it during the summer). There's Aveiro (the Portuguese Venice, as we nickname it). Guimarães was where the country was started and Bragança was the place of the monarchy's last dinasty.
I know some Northern parts of the country still have some Celtic roots and customs (such as in Podence, near Bragança).

This are some ideas that came to mind, so far.

Much like the rest of the new world, north Italian emigration was highest from ~1890 to ~1920 while southern Italian emigration peaked right after the Second World War until the 1960s. The older generation of Italian immigrants to Argentina were mostly genovesi/liguri and veneti/friulani with large amounts of Lombardi as well. Second wave was mostly campani, siciliani, and calabresi. The old generation of Italian immigrants were called Lunfardos, after their particular northern mixed dialect. Lunfardo is basically a dialect way of saying Lombardo. Tano became more popular in recent years to describe newer Italian immigrants, most of whom spoke variants of Neapolitan language.

This is called the modalist heresy because it treats the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost as different aspects of the same person. However, they are distinct persons from each other that simply share the same substance. What is the difference? Water cannot be simultaneously liquid, gas, and solid. God is simultaneously the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost. A father, son and engineer is not three distinct persons who can communicate with each other and have a relationship with each other, it is the same person just in different roles. The Son actually prays to the Father and he is not simply praying to himself but a distinct entity. Secondly, neither the Father nor the Holy Ghost were crucified nor experienced the sensation of death, but only the Son. Therefore, the Father, Son, and the Holy Ghost are not different modes of the same person.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14320089
A highly specific linguistic feature which points to harsh treatment of British natives in Anglo-Saxon society is the fate of the early Germanic word *walhaz in Old English. In the West Germanic ancestor of Old English, * walhaz meant ‘foreigner’, more specifically ‘Roman’, and even more specifically ‘person of Celtic or Romance speech’. The perspective here is that of a Germanic-speaking neighbour of the Western Roman Empire, living in what
are now the Low Countries and Germany. To him, his Roman neighbours would be culturally and linguistically clearly distinguishable from himself, being citizens of the Roman Empire and speaking either Latin or Celtic or
both. On the Continent, *walhaz survived into the later West Germanic languages as a term of reference to persons and areas of Romance speech. Old High German walh ‘person of Romance speech/origin’ and Dutch Waal ‘Walloon’ testify to that meaning. Place names containing the element *walhaz denote pockets in the Germanic-speaking world where Romance was spoken (e.g. Walchensee in Bavaria, Germany, and Waalwijk in North Brabant, Netherlands). A walnut (German Walnuss , Dutch walnoot ) is etymologically a nut from France. In Old English, *walhaz developed into
wealh. This retained the inherited meaning ‘a foreigner, more particularly a pre-Anglo-Saxon inhabitant of Britain who spoke Celtic or Latin or both’, but it is indicative of the social position of the British natives that in the
West Saxon dialect of Old English it acquired the new meaning ‘(British) slave’. The old feminine derivative of *walhaz , Old English wīln < *wīelen < *wealh-īn-, even exclusively means ‘a female slave’ and is likewise concentrated in the Saxon south of England. 6

>>14323661
Other way around. Mistranslated Bibles read: “In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God [Greek, ton the·on′], and the Word was God [the·os′].”

This verse contains two forms of the Greek noun the·os′ (god). The first is preceded by ton (the), a form of the Greek definite article, and in this case the word the·on′ refers to Almighty God. In the second instance, however, the·os′ has no definite article.

Now here is how the most accurate translations read:

1808: “and the word was a god.” The New Testament in an Improved Version, Upon the Basis of Archbishop Newcome’s New Translation: With a Corrected Text.

1864: “and a god was the word.” The Emphatic Diaglott, interlinear reading, by Benjamin Wilson.

1928: “and the Word was a divine being.” La Bible du Centenaire, L’Evangile selon Jean, by Maurice Goguel.

1935: “and the Word was divine.” The Bible—An American Translation, by J. M. P. Smith and E. J. Goodspeed.

1946: “and of a divine kind was the Word.” Das Neue Testament, by Ludwig Thimme.

1958: “and the Word was a God.” The New Testament, by James L. Tomanek.

Jesus is not just “a son of God.” Jesus is rightly called “the only-begotten Son of God.” (John 3:16, 18)

The Greek word translated “only-begotten” has been defined as “single of its kind, only,” “the only member of a kin or kind,” or “unique.” Jehovah has hundreds of millions of spirit sons but Jesus is the only one “of a kin or kind”

Jesus is unique in that he is the sole DIRECT creation of his Father. He is the firstborn Son. In fact, he is “the firstborn of all creation.” (Col. 1:15) He is “the beginning of the creation by God.” (Rev. 3:14)

The only-begotten Son’s role in creation is also unique. He was not the Creator, or Originator, of creation. But Jehovah used him as the agent, or means, to create all other things. (John 1:3.)

The apostle Paul wrote:
“There is actually to us one God the Father, out of whom all things are, and we for him; and there is one Lord, Jesus Christ, through whom all things are, and we through him.”—1 Cor. 8:6.

>Why does it sounds so different to other east Asian languages?
my theory is that it was because of contact with austronesian peoples, primarily the western austronesian. one of the characteristic of austronesian languages is that it's super easy to pronounce, you get one vowel and one consonant, combine them and it'll always sound the same all across the board. meanings are derived from different combination of syllables, not from difference in pronunciation or tones of the same syllables. when there's different meanings of the same word/syllables, it is derrived from the context of the sentence, not from different tone sounds.
compare that with the way chinese or korean are spoken.
that's also why japanese is among the easiest foreign language to spoke among maritime southeast asians (which is also why a lot of them became massive weebs). because they can basically skip the pronunciation class and goes straight to learning sentence structures.

>>14318066
>Modern Chinese has 2000 surnames in total but they accord prestige to the Original 507 for it meant your family line was old.

This isn't true at all.

The hundred family surnames doesn't contain all ancient traditional prestigious and rare Han surnames (such as Dongye 東野 and several others). The Dongye clan are literal primary main line descendants of the Duke of Zhou. Other extremely rare Han surnames include Hu (the Tiger one, also later adopted by Hui people who are not the same as the Han who carry it)

The first few surnames in the hundred family names are the surnames of the Song dynasty imperial family (Zhao) and then the Wuyue royal family (Qian).

There are also non-Han, Xianbei surnames in hundred family names like Dugu, Tuoba, Yuwen and Xiongnu surname like Huyan. These Xiongnu and Xianbei clans are far younger and far less prestigious than Dongye.

>>14314650

19th century Meiji Japanese peasants stole the ancient Han surname 東野 (the Japanese pronounce it as Higashano).

Han Chinese had the Dongye 東野 (Eastern Wild) surname since the Zhou dynasty nearly 3000 years ago since they were descended from the Duke of Zhou's descendants via his son Bo Qin, the Duke of Lu. Then thousands of years later in the 1800s Japanese peasants hijacked it.

The original Han Chinese Dongye noble family still exists today.

The Japanese pronunciation of the Wang surname sounds even more retarded. Japanese pronounce Wang as Ō.

Meanwhile Chinese pronounce "Japanese" surnames like Tagawa as Tianchuan.

You can't have it both ways, you deliberately didn't translate the meanings of the Chinese surnames .

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14318066
>>14323249
The Song dynasty compiled the hundreds family surnames for political reasons. They put their own imperial family surname and the allied Wuyue surname first, and left the actually prestigious Kong (Confucius) and Meng (Mencius) surnames for later, and included a bunch of Xianbei surnames and a Xiongnu surname because some Xianbei officials surnamed Yuwen served the Song government and a Xiongnu general surnamed Huyan served the Song military against the Khitan.

Meanwhile they left out rare but extremely ancient prestigious and noble aristocratic Han Chinese family surnames like Dongye dating back to the Western Zhou nobility and some rare single character Han surnames.

The hundred family surnames is not a list of Han only surnames neither is it an exhaustive list of Han surnames. It's a politically motivated work.

>Why were Cold War era communists in Poland, East Germany, USSR etc so much more comfortable accommodating historical nationalist imagery and dress
The political factions running a government decide what historic figures, movements and events get lauded and which get demonized or skipped over in education, public holidays, museums and monuments, etc. That in turn informs what is considered patriotic, who the national heroes and symbols are, what narrative of a national character is instilled in people's minds, all coming together to portray the current system and their ideology as the culmination of all that history and a victory of the Real [Insert Country Here]. Therefore it's not a surprise to see lots of patriotic and nationalist leftists in countries where leftists are controlling that process, and few patriotic and nationalist leftists in countries where rightists have been controlling that process. Enemy propaganda narratives aren't very appealing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14321339
https://desuarchive.org/int/thread/10916839/

1) Get Pimsleur Mandarin. It's not that expensive, although it's also available on torrent (not that you would steal copyrighted content now would you Anon?) Do a lesson every day until the sounds of the language are clear enough to you and you've learned some basic words. Don't worry too much about whether you've memorized all the course content.

2) Become familiar with the most common systems of Romanizing Mandarin Chinese, most importantly Hanyu Pinyin and Wade Giles.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romanization_of_Chinese

3) Download these two books.

Progressive exercises in the Chinese written language (1912)

http://archive.org/download/progressiveexerc00bull/progressiveexerc00bull.pdf

A Mandarin primer (1911)

http://archive.org/download/mandarinprimer00balluoft/mandarinprimer00balluoft.pdf

Go to page xix of "A Mandarin Primer". Start learning all of the 214 Radicals. If you study faithfully, it will take you perhaps a month or so to memorize them all. If it takes you longer, don't stress too much. But never skip a day, that's the most important thing ever. When you've learned all of the radicals, go to the first lesson in each book. In "Progressive exercises", the number of characters in each exercise are few enough that you can feasibly practice copying out all of the characters in each lesson.

Read one lesson every day of the texts in "A Mandarin Primer" every day too.

But the important thing is to WRITE ALL OF THE CHARACTERS IN EACH LESSON of "Progressive exercises" EVERY SINGLE DAY. Missing a day is catastrophic because you will forget the character learned in the previous lesson if you do this, and a few weeks later, you won't be able to understand the content of each new lesson anymore.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14323935
So yeah study both books every day, write all of the characters in each new lesson of "Progressive exercises" every day. It will take you six months to a year of doing this to fully commit 80%+ of the characters in both books to memory.

DON'T SKIP DAYS. And don't get discouraged. When you get to the end of either book, start at the beginning again. One book has 30 lessons, the other has more than 60, so in the course of a year you will have gone through both books several times. If you don't feel you've really got it down, well, just revise and revise and revise. Give it another year if you have to.

Do keep doing the Pimsleur as well while you're getting the reading and writing down.

After a year or two, congratulations! You know can read Mandarin and write Chinese - probably better than most Chinese. Newspapers, novels, political and historical texts not to mention pre-Revolutionary literature are all completely accessible to you.

You can't really speak Mandarin well, though yet can you? To practice your listening skills, go to RTI.tw and go 國語節目 (Mandarin) then 國語節目線上收聽. You can listen to News and cultural stuff. If that's a bit stiff for you, you can listen to pop and stuff here http://tunein.com/radio/Hit-FM-901-s91134/. Or just search for what you want on Google. Thanks to Chinese piracy you can watch all kinds of pirated content online (not that you would do that would you Anon?)

You can also practice speaking to Mandarin-speaking people on Sharedtalk.com. There are lots of language leeches though who won't speak to you in Mandarin unless you are much better at Mandarin than they are at English. Try your best though.

To keep practicing your reading skills, go to news.google.com and go to the China/Taiwan/Hong Kong sections. There are also lots of free books online, all kinds of Classical stuff that you will be able to read now are easily available.

Several reasons.

>First evidence of spears is more than 500,000 years ago by an unknown hominid species

It was very likely Homo rhodesiensis, an African species of human that existed both before and alongside early Homo sapiens. But you know what's really crazy? Homo naledi (another African species) despite their tiny orange sized brains, likely used fire to travel around in caves and cook, meaning their brains were far more complex than we give them credit for. Granted, their use of fire is also right around the time Homo sapiens was stomping around in Southern Africa, so there's always a chance for cultural exchange, but I'd like to think that they independently came up with fire too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The thought of all the (early) human experiences lost to prehistory makes my head spin. I can't imagine what it would be like to live back then, but I can't help but put together these vague associative constructs. Fear and brutality mixed with childhood lucidity. Animal smells and the touch of wood on callused hands. Rhythmic movement under an unpolluted sky.
I know it's about as real as some warped bucolic fantasy, but there is a feeling behind it that has this strange solid quality. Like the image of a millenia-old vampire dining on silver plates, in candlelight, inside a dirty rundown 21st century building amidst empty plastic bottles, used up spray cans, fast fashion rags and used condoms.

If someone suggested to me that that book or an adaptation of it ought to be censored or changed because it doesn't fit with some modern multikulti concept of political correctness I would be mortified. Just because you don't like the context in which something was produced it doesn't mean that that context must be erased or that understanding that context has no value.

Pretending that we always lived in some post-racial utopia - and avoiding anything that goes contrary to that narrative - seems to me more about erasing white liberal guilt than anything else. Something like Bridgerton is the perfect example of that. In imagining a post-racial version of Regency England - and casting blacks and Indians in English aristocratic roles - the show erases the reality of that time period for black and brown people and pretends they were always part of some imagined multicultural imperial elite. To me that is a far greater tragedy and perversion of history than having an all-white cast.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Was digging around some books and archeology papers, and found this gem.

Sarai Nahar Rai represents the oldest hunter gatherer skeleton found in South Asia so far, dated to 8000 BC. The skeletal remains of around 11? people show a very tall, robust population of hunter gatherers using microlith technology. In my previous research, I noticed that some European hunter gatherers like SHG also had the same industry. The authors compare Euro and Indian HGs in a paper but I couldn't understand their main point.

Anyway, I wanted to share some cool data here and encourage discussion of these fossils. I notice immediately that the cranial and facial features described here (wide zygomatic breadth, pronounced parietal, very strong brow ridge) are all common among modern day South Indians, but also North Indians as well. This skeleton was found in North India actually, which may reflect a regional difference among AASI groups.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Here's the most intact skull they found among the skeletons. The cranial capacity was measured to be 1450 cm3, which is way above modern averages and considerably high for prehistoric people too

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14321345

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14321359
Here's a page from one of the papers I found. It details the bones on the skeletons, especially the male ones.
According to the analysis, these men were very robust and muscular. You can tell because the greater/lesser tuberosity on the clavicle, femur, humerus, etc were very pronounced, meaning that large muscle attachments were present. In general, looking at sulci (grooves) and tuberosities in bone are the golden standard for understanding build and morphology.
Apart from that, the bones themselves were pretty huge and particularly hard. Supposedly a "metal like" ring could be heard upon striking the femur, which indicates no osteoporosis or weakness within the bone. The rib cages were also quite massive, at least in the male skeletons.

This stuff is fascinating to me as a medical student, since I'm learning about MSK anatomy right now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In terms of skull measurements, you could probably say these people were dolichocephalic or long headed. If someone else wants to run the numbers and calculate a cranial index, please go ahead. Pic related are the relevant measurements. Researchers noted a moderately long skull with considerable breadth.

Again, the striking thing here is the massive cranial capacity. 1450 cm3 is very far above the average for modern humans. IIRC for Asians and Europeans its around 1360 cm3.

>>14321400
iirc what is often apparent with older sapiens pops and archaics with large cranial capacities is the increased occipital space. Modern pops with the largest skulls (North Siberians) fare pretty poorly on IQ tests relative to their massive relative surplus in volume. Comparing sequenced archaeological genomes to recent ones for alleles associated in GWAS's with educational attainment, a proxy measurement for IQ, show a historical increase in frequency as one closes in on the present. Big brain =/= smart, but it does give you something. I'm laying in bed and don't have to paper- iirc despite having smaller brains overall, aboriginal australians had more developed occipital lobes and excelled at visual processing compared to European-descended controls. Similar results have been proven for the aforementioned polar peoples, who do actually have larger skulls than settled ones. That extra brain is doing something. However, not all domain-specific intelligence is equally useful. Domain-general IQ does correlate in other studies with cranial capacity. It would be interesting to see GWAS's that focus on the g factor or domain-general intelligence and then compare these mesolithic sapiens. Were they adept spearchucker retards or clever improvisers?

>>14311860
When it comes to pieces like this >>14311569, there is actually some substance you can talk about. The flowing hair forces your eye to glide from left to right, first catching a form like a little girl being seized by a brute. The exaggerated anatomy oozes the contrast between rough and soft. Go a bit to the right and it seems like she's pushing him away, but then you see the comforting embrace - you look back and what looked like a girl shyly drawing away from a man looks like a boy desperate for comfort drawing towards a woman.
It's a simple play on the ideas of masculinity and feminity, taking and giving. It's subtle and beautiful.
Contrast with Hitler's kitschy mess >>14311788.

Greek art is a dead end though. It attained its goal -- perfectly representing the (idealised) human body -- and then stagnated, since its art doesn't express any higher symbolic, emotional, or religious vision. This is one way in which the Renaissance improved on the Greeks. It wedded physicality to spirituality. It had more room to explore.
>>14311908
>like every pre-modern artist they aimed for realism even though they weren't good at it
They did not. Cave painters can draw quite realistic depictions of animals and animal movement. Byzantine artists are not doing this. They were trying to represent profound mystic and religious truths through complex symbolism and beautiful geometric arrangements. Pic related is a photorealistic drawing of a black child by a modern artist. It is much less interesting than Byzantine art.

>>14312091
It's kind of like with poetry, anon. If you try to express an experience through strictly accurate words, it won't have as much emotional impact because the reader won't have the context nor be in the same headspace as you were. That's why you need to set the scene, and the best way to do that is through means which create an analogous narrative using unrealistic but evocative tools. The poet is like a magician trying to hijack your brain using tricks and swindles, pulling hidden levers and driving you into the scene that he wants you to see.
Visual art can be very similar.

>>14312151
I'll give you an example. Do you know why artists bother with figure drawing? You need to know anatomy really well to be able to accurately picture a person. If you don't have it drilled into your head how all the muscle groups work, you'll picture something a bit symbolic and quite inaccurate, but your brain will fill in the blanks in such a way that will give you the illusion of accuracy. And this will happen to some extent even if you know your anatomy, but that's beside the point.
Try to paint a human body from memory. Even if you can't draw, it should have all the basic components put together in a way that resembles the actual working structure of the body if you can picture a human accurately in your mind. Protip: you won't be able to do this because the picture in your head isn't accurate.

An investigative study was carried out on the familial relationships of a number of late 18th dynasty mummies (ca. 1550–1295 b.c.), including that of Tutankhamen. The study was based on the analysis of the autosomal and Y-chromosome STR markers in addition to mitochondrial hypervariable region 1 sequences. A 4-generation pedigree of Tutankhamun’s immediate lineage and the identity of his ancestors were established. The Royal male lineage was the Y-chromosome haplogroup R1b that was passed from the grandparent (Amenhotep III) to the father (KV55, Akhenaten) to the grandchild (Tutankhamen). The maternal lineage, the mitochondrial haplogroup K, extended from the great-grandmother (Thuya) to the grandmother (KV35 Elder lady, Queen Tiye) to the yet historically unidentified mother (KV35 Younger lady) to Tutankhamen (38,55).

>Gad et al

One time I listened to Dio's entire discography and thought I'd detected certain, not some much Evolian, as maybe Perennialist or Eastern philosophical themes (Evola being adjacent to these), maybe filtered down by means of more popular occultists (Crowley et al were somewhat popular in the rock scene), so I read his authorized bio (pic related).

I thought I'd caught glimpses of Brahman in the Man on the Silver Mountain
>I'm a wheel, I'm a wheel
>I'm the sun, I'm the sun

The Maitrâyana Brâhmana Upanishad says
>he saw Brahman, flashing like a wheel on fire, bright like the sun, vigorous, beyond all darkness, that which shines forth in yonder sun, in the moon, in the fire, in the lightning

Again in Sacred Heart
>Turning like a wheel
>You've got to reach for the sun
>And find the sacred heart
>Somewhere bleeding in the night
The night is considered a symbol of the non-manifest in Perennialist writings.

The song Sacred Heart flies under the radar, but Guenon wrote about the symbolism of the Sacred Heart in The Symbolism of the Grail.

And who is the Man on the Mountain, who cries: "Come and make me holy again"? I wondered if he might not be Shiva and the Silver Mountain, Mount Kailash. Shaivites consider Shiva as the Supreme Brahman. He is non dual:
>I'm the dark and the light
And is the Self inside your self:
>With eyes that see inside you

One is reminded of Dante in La Divina Commedia

Oh you who have sane intellects

If we were to accept the hypothesis that Dio took the phrase from Evola (and it's just a hypothesis) what would follow? What did the tiger represent in Evola? Samsaric existence, in the Kali Yuga specifically.
The song goes
>Ride the tiger
>You can see his stripes but you know he's clean
The tiger (Samsara, Kali Yuga) seems fearful, impure, but ultimate reality in non-dual. The Heart Sutra says that Nirvana neither pure nor impure. Ultimately Samsara and Nirvana are non different. Likewise, in the Kali Yuga, the seemingly impure Shaivic and Tantric left-hand practices can lead to liberation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14320823 Cont.
Alternatively, clean can mean free from samsaric defilements. The one reality, Brahman, that appears as Maya or the menacing tiger to us down here, is ever free from defilement.
Our Upanishad says
>There are two manifestations of the Brahma-light: one is tranquil, the other lively.
Brahman as he is in himself is immutable, clear and shiny as the sun; but ever-changing like a cloud or a sea, as he appears to us in the guise of Maya or the tiger, which deep inside is "clean".
Near the ending the song reveals that
>You're the one who's clean
You, atman, samsarim, holy diver, who's been "down too long in the midnight sea" and who's forgotten who he really is, you're the one who's clean; your essence and that of the tiger are one and the same: you are that, you are Brahman.

Another cryptic verse is this
>You can hide in the sun 'till you see the light
What tf does it mean to hide in the sun? How does one hide in the sun?
The Maitrâyana Brâhmana Upanishad says
>the adorable splendour of Savitri (sun) is to be meditated on by him who, abiding within his mind, meditates thereon. Here he attains the place of rest for the mind, he holds it within his own Self.
One "hides" in the sun, as it were, by meditating upon it until he sees the light? What light?
>That which is true is Brahman, that which is Brahman is light, and that which is light is the Sun 5. And this Sun became the Self of that Om.

>Gotta get away, get away

>Something is coming for you
>Look out

>You've been down too long in the midnight sea
Guenon and Evola say that the ever mutable sea is a symbol os Samsara.

>Like the eyes of a cat in the black and blue
Black and blue = night sea = samsara.
The deluded samsarim sees the tiger/the world/samsaric existence as other than his true Self, and is afraid of it. He sees the tiger as chasing him. Another song (Hungry for Heaven) talks about a dreamer ("We are like the dreamer who dreams, and then lives inside the dream." ... >You're a runner
>But you're chasing yourself
>Feel a hot breath on your shoulder
The tiger is the man chasing himself, but he doesn't realize due to his identification with the body and his dualistic mind.

>>14323405
>>no remaining objects tied to jesus (i.e., home, manuscripts, the cross he was supposedly crucified on)
Not surprising.
>>absolutely no mention of pontius pilate of roman record
What do you mean by Roman records? He's mentioned in Tacitus and we have an inscription with his name
>>no mention of jesus in antiquated historical records besides one, which was written by josephus
No, Josephus is just the most reliable scholarly source on the subject. We have plenty of primary sources. That the Christian bible is horribly bias and incorrect on many points does not make it less important as a source. This is something non-historians seem to have trouble wrapping their heads around, but in fact we just assume even scholars like Tacitus and Josephus had their own agendas and were probably willing to twist the truth for the sake of their premises. A big part of historical scholarship is learning to work around that.
>the entire belief that jesus was real hinges on the fact that josephus was a jew and supposedly wouldn't have written about jesus because of that
No, that is a big data point which makes the mythicist position less convincing than it already is, but the historical Jesus would be the better hypothesis even without it.

God created things which had free will. That means creatures which can go wrong or right. Some people think they can imagine a creature which was free but had no possibility of going wrong, but I can't. If a thing is free to be good it's also free to be bad. And free will is what has made evil possible. Why, then, did God give them free will? Because free will, though it makes evil possible, is also the only thing that makes possible any love or goodness or joy worth having. A world of automata -of creatures that worked like machines- would hardly be worth creating. The happiness which God designs for His higher creatures is the happiness of being freely, voluntarily united to Him and to each other in an ecstasy of love and delight compared with which the most rapturous love between a man and a woman on this earth is mere milk and water. And for that they've got to be free.
Of course God knew what would happen if they used their freedom the wrong way: apparently, He thought it worth the risk. (...) If God thinks this state of war in the universe a price worth paying for free will -that is, for making a real world in which creatures can do real good or harm and something of real importance can happen, instead of a toy world which only moves when He pulls the strings- then we may take it it is worth paying.

>>14322693
>First among equals status doesn't authorize the altering of an ecumenical creed

Canon VII of the Council of Ephesus (A.D. 431) was no barrier to the inclusion of Filioque:

>The holy Council decrees that no one should be permitted to offer a different Creed of Faith, or in any case, to write or compose another, than the one defined by the holy fathers who convened in the city of Nicaea...
Canon VII, Council of Ephesus

Note that the Canon VII prohibition is against adding to the Creed “defined by the holy fathers who convened in the city of Nicaea” (A.D. 325). Now, the Creed of Nicaea makes no mention of the Spirit’s procession, but merely reads:

>[We believe] in the Holy Sprit...

So if Canon VII invalidates the addition of the Filioque made by the Catholic Church at the regional Council of Toledo (A.D. 589) (to address an argument made by the Spanish Arians), an addition, btw, to the Latin translation only (the Greek text was never touched), then it likewise invalidates the Constantinopolitan Creed itself, since Constantinople I (A.D. 381) also “added to” the Creed of Nicaea (with its additional clause referring to the Spirit’s procession).

Note: This is a paraphrase of the analysis set forth on pages 5-6 of this article that responds to EO objections to the Filioque:
https://www.catholicbridge.com/downloads/response-on-the-filioque.pdf

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14322887

>>14322887
>Yes but the council of Constantinople was ecumenical...

Constantinople was a regional council that only achieved ecumenical status when the Pope signed on to it. But when the Council added the procession clause, it was a mere regional council of the Eastern Church in which the West did not participate. Again, further detail backing up this point is set forth on page 6 and elsewhere in the above-linked article.

Also, note that Canon VII says "no one," with no exceptions. I.e., no exceptions for ecumenical councils. Thus if one holds Canon VII as authority against Rome adding the Filioque, then, to be consistent, it would seem that one must likewise so hold vis a vis the addition of the procession clause at Constantinople I.

>I say it by the way, I think it's true and biblical, I just place shared blame upon the west for the schism
There's no doubt it added fuel to the fire of the eventual schism.

>>14319357

My understanding is that the Austro-Hungarian collapse was largely a consequence of the Bulgarian one. That opened up AH's entire southern border to attack, which in turn led to the Hungarians demanding that their troops be withdrawn from the Italian Front to protect Hungary's own borders. There was, of course, no way that AH could man another front. Even so, though, the KuK army continued fighting for several days after the monarchy it served had begun to break up. Take away the collapse in Macedonia and there's no reason why that should happen.

So it's really down to the Bulgarians. However, they didn't quit until late September, when it was clear that Germany herself was on the ropes and would never be able to assist them as, had she been doing better on the Western Front, she could have done.

The essential point is that Germany's allies collapsed because Germany herself was collapsing, not vice versa. As long as Germany is doing okay in France and Belgium, she will find the means to prop her allies up.
